resources.string: Set preferred apps for hosts they support
Tap here to make LinkSheet the default browser
Tap an app to open the \"Open by default\" menu which allows you to disable automatic link opening
Lists all apps which may interfere with LinkSheet\'s behavior
No apps have been set as preferred yet.
Shows a \"Copy URL\" button in the bottom sheet
URL has been copied to clipboard
Only require one tap instead of two to open apps; Long-press to select app, double click to open app info
Include Android system usage stats in sorting algorithm. Permission is requested on first toggle.
Only list native apps, remove all browsers. If only a single native app is present, it will automatically be opened. If no native app is present, all browsers are listed.
No app to handle link found!
Shows a button in the bottom sheet which allows you to share the URL to other apps as if you selected it from a \"Share to\" menu
Always show the package names instead of just app names. This applies to the whole app.
Automatically hide bottom sheet when an action button such as \"Copy link\" or \"Download\" is tapped
Show a grid instead of a list in the bottom sheet
LinkSheet has been set as default browser!
This browser will automatically be opened if no native app can handle the clicked link
Grid layout, sort by usage, tap customization, url-bar
Use experimental ClearURLs integration (clears tracking parameters from URLs)
Automatically follow all redirects before opening bottom sheet. This may have privacy-related implications
Follow redirects using an API deployed at supabase.com (Privacy policy)
Only attempt to follow redirects when the host is known to be a tracker/redirect. If \"Follow redirects via external service\" is enabled, this will always be enabled.
Material You, dark theme, pure black mode
Use experimental FastForward rule integration (bypass redirects of some hosts by extracting redirect from link)
Cache the result of redirects locally
Redirect links to privacy friendly frontends using experimental LibRedirect integration
Don\'t show the top section which suggests the last used app for the clicked host
Use simple text buttons for \"Copy URL\", \"Share to\", \"Download\" and \"Ignore LibRedirect\"
Replaces the \"Copy URL\", \"Share to\", \"Download\" and \"Ignore LibRedirect\" outlined buttons with simple text buttons
Shows the clicked URL (after it has been processed)
Add a \"Download\" button to the bottom sheet if URL contains direct link to file. This may have privacy-related implications
Checks if the URL ends with a file extension (e.g. \".jpg\"); If it does, this type is used for the downloaded file.
Apps decide if the In-App browser should be used
Disable the In-App browser in all apps
Disable the In-App browser in selected apps
No apps which can handle links have been found.
Shows a button in the bottom sheet if the URL has been redirected via LibRedirect, which opens the original URL instead
Looks like LinkSheet has crashed, checkout the error below
This session does not contain any logs.
Defines how many seconds LinkSheet will wait for a connection to be established. Setting this to 0 disables the timeout, but this is not recommended.
Displays a button next to browsers which opens the clicked URL in private browsing mode. Supported browsers: %s
Redact log (recommended, disabling this may leak package names and host names)
To learn about log privacy, you can visit this link.
Redirects AMP pages to their normal web version. This may have privacy-related implications
Cache the retrieved non-AMP versions of webpages locally
Attempt to obtain non-AMP page version via external service
Attempt to obtain non-AMP page version using an API deployed at supabase.com (Privacy policy)
Use built-in cache (which uses a database export of the external service)
Enabling a lot of buttons in the bottom sheet currently may lead to cut off/glitching buttons.
Enabling this applies the settings below to both Normal and In-App link handling. Use the buttons below to switch between Normal and In-App mode when disabled.
This switch will be moved to a different location in a future release.
Shizuku lets LinkSheet interact with system APIs directly

Enabling this will allow LinkSheet to use Shizuku to interact with system APIs directly. This can be used, for example, to automatically disable all link-handlers. A new option will show up on the main app screen.
Shizuku mode activated, tap an app to toggle its automatic link handling capabilities. Long tap an app to open its \"Open by default\" settings menu.
Shizuku integration has been successfully enabled!
Shizuku is not running. Tap here to open Shizuku, then follow the instructions to start it.
Tap here to request Shizuku permission.
While not strictly necessary for LinkSheet to work, Shizuku is recommended. Tap here to install it.
LinkSheet \"restores\" the \"url-app-chooser\" that appeared when the user tapped a link on Android <12 and had multiple apps installed which could handle the link

In order for LinkSheet to operate, it needs to be set as the systems browser, so it can intercept link clicks. Don\'t worry, LinkSheet has plenty of customizability options, so this will not limit, but rather enhance your experience.
Toggle off linkhandling to make LinkSheet

In Android 12, Google introduced Verified App Links. Apps can now cryptographically verify ownership of domains. When a link to such a domain is tapped, and the corresponding app is installed, it will automatically open by default, skipping the choice that was previously given to the user entirely.

This is highly annoying, as sometimes, you don't want to open a link in its app, but rather in a browser (for example, to bookmark it).

Ahh, classic Google, crippling their own products without a simple way to restore the old behavior

 Anyway, they left a small "loophole": Link-handling can be disabled on a per-app basis. You may assume that this would bring back to old app chooser, but of course (thanks Google!), that's not the case, as now, the link will always open in your default browser. That's why LinkSheet was created.
Pretend to be a native app for supported domains with LinkSheetCompat

Some apps like Google Chrome explicitly search for a native app to handle, for example, a Youtube link when it is tapped in the search results. LinkSheetCompat pretends to be such a native app for supported hosts and then forwards the request to LinkSheet.
No browser or native app found!
LinkSheet can not open this link.
LinkSheet has detected at least one app known to be a browser.
LinkSheet has detected at least one app claiming to be a browser. LinkSheet\'s list may not be complete. If you think this is an error, submit an issue on Github.
LinkSheet was unable to detect at least one application claiming to be a browser. For the best experience, install a browser.
Are you sure you want to set %s as the preferred application for the following domains?
If you like LinkSheet, consider leaving a star on Github and/or donating.\nDonators who donate more than 5€ are eligible for LinkSheet Pro, which will have exclusive features.
LinkSheet was initially based on OpenLinkWith
Seal has been a great resource to learn from regarding Jetpack Compose
Mastodon Redirect\'s source code was used as a reference for Shizuku interaction
Importer for preferences contained in logs files - probably not useful for the average user

When an app is launched, it can check to see which app launched, or \"referred\" to it. By default, when LinkSheet launches an app, it hides itself, saying that the app that launched LinkSheet is the launched target. Enable this to reinsert LinkSheet as the referrer for apps it opens.
When donating with crypto, send an email to 1fexd@420blaze.it.
A donation of more than 5€ allows you access to LinkSheet Pro, which includes Pro exclusive features such as: following redirects externally, obtaining non-AMP pages externally and more to come!
This build was neither signed by 1fexd nor the Github workflow.
This is a LinkSheet Pro feature!
Export your current settings or import a previous settings export
Export your current app settings to a file
Import a previous export from a file
Include log hash key (the key used to redact your logs)
Include history (your link click and app history)
We recommend that you turn on the following settings only if you do not plan on sharing your export with someone else!
To learn about export privacy, you can visit this link.
This will override all existing preferences. Continue?
Congratulations, you have enabled dev-mode. Just be cautious.
Show a toast when an URL is copied by the user
Show a toast when a download has been started
Show a toast when an app that has been set as default for a domain is launched
Show a toast when a URL is resolved via an external service
Show a toast when an URL fails to resolve via an external service
Enable the experimental LinkSheet Compat menu
The menu can be found in the sub-menu \"Apps\" and when installed, is able to intercept requests to certain native apps.
In additional to being an experimental feature, LibRedirect is currently considered very unstable and may not work at all.
Use the reworked bottom sheet instead of the old one

This version of LinkSheet features a new bottom sheet thanks to @sakethpathike! Please provide feedback on Discord, Github or via email.\n\nYou can revert to the old bottom sheet via Settings -> Advanced -> Feature flags.
Failed to start Shizuku Manager, please start it manually!
Include crash logs (recommended, but can not be redacted)
%s is either blocked or does not exist
Enable the latest bottomsheet version which is currently in development
Choose to always get prompted when opening a link, set default browsers, and much more
LinkSheet\'s functionality requires custom Android configuration. The following setup will guide you through the multi-step process.
LinkSheet needs to be set as default browser to handle tapped links
LinkSheet can not function without being the default browser.
Do you want to use Shizuku?
If you have a lot of apps installed, Shizuku may significantly improve your experience
Shizuku allows LinkSheet to disable the default link handling behavior of all apps at once, instead of having to manually disable them for each app individually (which is the next step).
Link handlers need to be disabled so LinkSheet can intercept them
Google introduced verified app links in Android 12, which allows apps to cryptographically proof ownership of domains. This behavior must be manually disabled for LinkSheet to intercept tapped links.
Disable link handling for all domains that should be handled by LinkSheet.
Basic configuration required for LinkSheet to function has been done - head to the settings to explore what else it has to offer!
Don\'t like the new bottom sheet? Tap to report issues.

The new bottom sheet is nearing feature completion. Notably, tap customization is not yet available and will be implemented at a later date.\nPlease report bugs either on Github, Discord, or via Email.
Resolve embed mirrors like fxtwitter.com to the real host
Hide the \"Once\" and \"Always\" buttons in the bottom sheet
Some imported preferences require permissions that are currently not given to LinkSheet. Tap below to request them.
Declutter the url in the bottom sheet
Declutter the url in the bottom sheet by removing the scheme (if https) and the \"www\" subdomain if present
Tap to check out features currently in development
Parse shared text if no url is found
When the share action is invoked from an app which shares text containing an url, attempt to find (and use) the first url in the text instead of failing
Experiments are under active development and may not work correctly, or at all. Please do not report bugs on Github. If you want to provide feedback, do so on Discord.
Use pure black theme if dark mode is enabled
Use Android 12+\'s Material You device theme
Choose the action that should be performed
Expand when an app is selected
Automatically expand the bottom sheet when an app is selected
LinkSheet is performing link operations. This will only take a few seconds
Display a label next to apps which natively support the opened link
Choose the type of usage metrics you are most comfortable with.

Usage metrics include a random, user-resettable installation-bound identifier, as well as your Android version, and are stored at Aptabase (EU). Sensitive data, such as installed apps and clicked links will never be collected. To learn more, tap here.
LinkSheet can not handle this link as it appears to be malformed. You can edit it below, then try again. Alternatively, you can search on the web.
Something went wrong, please try again.
Tap here to reset the app-link verification status of all apps, then wait a few minutes while Android re-verifies them. You will not receive a confirmation. Requires Shizuku.

Displays a button in the bottom sheet to open the tapped link in a (work-) profile. Requires LinkSheet to be installed in both profiles, and manually linked via Settings -> Special app access -> Connected work & personal apps
Update LinkSheet to the latest version
Default browser-, link handling-, connected apps settings
Recommended, redacts app names and urls
Recommended, but can not be redacted
To learn more about potentially sensitive data in shared log files, tap here.
Configure share settings for log captured at: %s
Aww snap, that should not have happened!
LinkSheet is correctly set up and ready to operate
LinkSheet is not set as the system\'s default browser
LinkSheet has been given a fresh coat of paint!
Don\'t run Amp2Html if the app launching LinkSheet is known to be a browser
Don\'t attempt to follow redirects if the app launching LinkSheet is known to be a browser
